text: Hadn't remembered Thomas Paine's Common Sense being so insanely based. americainclass.org/wp-conten‚Ä¶
We know it's a mistaken transcription because the KJV has 666, and Solemn Providence trumps secular history.
I'm not saying it's great, but what is?

"The rich are in general slaves to fear, and submit to courtly power with the trembling duplicity of a spaniel." 
-- Paine on Bezos.

"There are thousands, and tens of thousands, who would think it glorious to expel from the continent that barbarous and hellish power which hath stirred up the Indians and the Negroes to destroy us."
-- Paine on my Twitter TL.
My head-scratcher of the day: Why doesn't Yarvin just come out as a Hobbesian? ...
... I'm not going to call him a 'Neo-Hobbesian' until I can find a single point of disagreement, however trivial.
There is absolutely no possible way that Yarvin is more of an empiricist than Hobbes.
The Neo-Cameralism was actually something outside of Hobbes, but it seems to have been now entirely retracted.
Isn't he, though? Covid-19 is softly chuckling right now.
... Hobbes describes himself as pitifully craven, but he published things that could have got him physically destroyed, under several regimes.

... To put this as cattily as possible -- which is utterly outrageous given what UR meant to me -- the first 20 pages of Hobbes discussion of 'Common-wealth' in Leviathan is basically an executive summary of the whole of Gray Mirror (except the dating app.) in sulfurous English.
That's all been retracted, hasn't it? Cite me something from GM in similar vein and I'll seriously reconsider.
